The reason you use J2MEUnit is that it allows you to test your code with the
J2ME KVM. JUnit won't do that.

In testing against the KVM, we found all kinds of J2ME-specific things that
we needed to change.

If you need to startup your MIDlet to test pieces of your application, might
I suggest that your application might be too closely tied to your
implementation platform? The same design logic applies to MIDlets as it does
to any sort of GUI application. Keep your business logic separate from your
presentation logic. This lets you test your business logic without having to
set up all the context stuff that MIDlets need. This is the same thing I
recommend and do when I write applets, servlets, etc. If you make those
classes dumb, then you can test the rest of your system without them. And
you also have a lot more flexibility in how you deploy your business logic,
as it is not tied to a particular platorm implementation.

We actually did what you said, and had J2MEUnit start up inside a MIDlet
which we ran on one of the emulators. But, we were still testing out the
business logic of our system, not the MIDlet itself.

> Brian Button wrote:
> >What we did, and as I recommend to my clients, is to separate out the
> >plumbing logic (the MIDlet) from the business logic. Have the MIDlet
> >create and call the business logic, but keep that creation logic
> >really simple. Put all the complexity into the business logic classes,
> >which are a lot easier to test.
>
> But, why use j2meUnit then? if you test only the "non midp specific" logic
> you can also relay on JUnit.
> I found it very easy to modify the test suit to run as midlet on an
> emulator, now you can use the textui to assert RMS operations etc.
>
> I recommend to invoke testsuites from midlets added to your suite, on
deploy
> you can easly remove them.
